title: NYC AlgoMatcher
description: An interactive website to help NYC residents identify which city agency algorithms, as reported under Local Law 35, may process their data

title: NYC Iconic Run Clubs
description: At 2025 Open Data Week, I attended Dan DeWitz's session on mapping NYC's best sandwiches with AI, featuring a playful site inspired by a New York Times list. Fresh off a half marathon, I created a healthier homage, a map of run clubs across New York City.

title: Transit Deserts in NYC
description: I mapped the NYC subway network system (network, nodes, flows, and agents) using GTFS data and ArcGIS Pro's Network Analyst Toolkit to assess dead transit zones in a city often hailed for having the nation's best transit system.

title: Predictive Maintenance of NYC Subway Disruptions
description: I co-designed a predictive maintenance framework using linear models, tree-based algorithms, and K-Means clustering to quantify disruption probabilities, passenger delays, and identify high-impact subway lines. I presented the findings as a white paper to the NYC Open Data Team during Open Data Week to support prioritized MTA intervention.

title: IntelliBART Database Management System
description: I independently built IntelliBART, a relational database management system (RDBMS) integrating Bay Area Rapid Transit (BART) ridership data with GTFS geospatial files. I designed an ETL pipeline and robust database schema to help urban data enthusiasts explore and analyze transit trends.

title: BART Ridership Analytics
description: Inspired by Ben Wellington's I Quant NYC and Abhishek Roy's Commute Chronicles, I took a deep dive into Bay Area transit ridership trends, leveraging novel methodologies in advanced ML and time-series forecasting.

title: ESRI Developer & Technology Summit 2025
description: Supported event logistics as a student assistant while gaining exposure to emerging GIS technologies and geospatial applications of AI and LLMs

title: ESRI User Conference 2025
description: Supported event logistics as a student assistant while gaining exposure to emerging GIS technologies and geospatial applications of AI and LLMs

title: MakAR for Cornell Tech's MakerLAB
description: MakAR is an AR tool that shows step-by-step instructions through smart glasses to help new makers use lab equipment safely and on their own. Lab staff can update instructions through a dashboard to keep things running smoothly.

title: Impact of Selective Migration Policies on Foreign Student Migration and Patenting in the USA
description: Researched history of visa programs (F-1, OPT-STEM, H1-B) to identify suitable intervention periods and control groups; Conducted Difference-in-Difference analysis with three intervention periods to assess impacts over time and authored paper

title: How does disinformation spread?
description: Tasked with designing survey experiment in English and Hindi to investigate belief adaption amid social media misinformation; Crafted neutral questions to capture participants' shifts in belief when reacting to newspaper and social media clippings in survey; Deployed survey experiment among friends/family in India to boost experiment participation and capture diverse perspectives

title: Taxonomic Database System of Hawaiian Species
description: Co-digitized Elwood Zimmerman's seven multivolume series on Hawaiian insect taxonomy into a database in Microsoft Access; Organized taxonomical information and species interrelationships into a digitally accessible and searchable format

title: Project Manager at Microfinance at Berkeley
Tree-planting strategies in NYC
description: Developed data-driven sustainable tree-planting strategies using QGIS, directly influencing decisions made by New Yorkers for Parks

title: Disaster Tweet Classification using Natural Language Processing
description: I engineered an NLP model to classify tweets as disaster-related or not, achieving 89.2% accuracy on the test set. I built a preprocessing pipeline consisting of stopword removal, lemmatization, and vectorization. Then, I applied feature extraction techniques like Bag of Words and N-Grams to train Logistic Regression and Bernoulli Naive Bayes models.
